messages.content:
Based on this resume, give the user the information they need: 
# Viplav Fauzdar
**? **? • Phone: 678-462-4453 • Email: viplav.fauzdar@gmail.com
LinkedIn: https://linkedin.com/in/viplavfauzdar • GitHub: https://github.com/viplavfauzdar

## Summary
* Senior Software Engineer & Architect with 25+ years delivering secure, scalable enterprise applications for Fortune 1000 companies and government agencies. Expert in Java, Spring
* Boot, cloud-native platforms (AWS, GCP, Azure), and Dev Sec Ops with deep security tooling integration across CI/CD pipelines. Proven leader in Agile environments, mentoring teams and modernizing legacy systems.
* Recent focus on AI-powered solutions using Lang Chain, RAG, Ollama, n8n, Py Torch, and
* Tensor Flow — building intelligent automation, real-time analytics, and self-hosted LLM workflows. Skilled in thre at modeling, AI thre at review, and secure SDLC for high-compliance environments.

## Skills

Programming & Frameworks:

Java (8-21), J2EE, Spring Boot, Spring Framework (Data, Security, MVC, Cloud, Batch, JPA, JDBC), Node. js, Python, Flask, Fast API, JavaScript (ES6+), TypeScript, React. js, Angular, Astro, Tailwind CSS, HTML5, CSS3, REST APIs, Graph QL, g RPC

Cloud & DevOps:

Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud Platform (GCP), Microsoft Azure, Pivotal Cloud Foundry (PCF), Docker, Kubernetes (K8s), Terraform, Jenkins, GitHub Actions, Vault, Apigee, OAuth2, JWT, AWS Lambda, SQS, SNS, Cloud Pub/Sub, Dataflow, ETL Pipelines

Security & Dev Sec Ops:

Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC), Test-Driven Development (TDD), Behavior-Driven Development (BDD), Static Application Security Testing (SAST - Sonar Qube, Code QL), Software Composition Analysis (SCA - OWASP Dependency-Check, Dependabot), Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST - OWASP ZAP), Container Security (Docker Scout, Trivy, Snyk), Secret Detection (GitHub Advanced Security, Gitleaks), Infrastructure as Code (Ia C) Security, AI Thre at Modeling, False Positive Tuning

AI/ML & Data:
* Generative AI (Gen AI), Agentic AI, AI Agents, AI Experience Design (AX), Retrieval-Augmented
* Generation (RAG), Lang Chain, Hugging Face Transformers, Ollama, GPT-OSS-20B, LLa MA,
* Mistral, Gemma, Phi Models, Py Torch, Tensor Flow, Gradio, Streamlit, Chroma DB, LM Studio,
* MLX, Big Query, Spanner, Cassandra, MongoDB, Neo4j, Oracle, MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL
* Server, DB2, DynamoDB, Aurora, RDS

Testing, Monitoring & Quality:

JUnit, Mockito, Cucumber, Gherkin, Cypress, Ja Co Co, JMeter, Prometheus, Grafana, Splunk, Micrometer, Spring Boot Actuator, Swagger, Lombok, Postman, Artifactory

## Tools & Platforms

Cursor, Visual Studio Code, IntelliJ IDEA, JIRA, Confluence, n8n, Reflex. dev, UI/UX, Playwright

## Experience

AI Engineer - Self-Employed | Atlanta, GA | Jan 2025 - Present? Built AI-powered stock trading bot with Lang Chain, Open AI, Alpaca SDK, and Py Torch for live trading, strategy generation, and backtesting.? Developed multimedia RAG app with OCR, transcription, semantic search, and LLM querying via Streamlit and Docker.? Integrated self-hosted LLMs (LLaMA3, GPT-OSS-20B) using Ollama for privacy-first, context-aware workflows.

Senior Software Engineer (Contractor) - The Home Depot Warehouse | Atlanta, GA | Sept 2024 - Jan 2025? Designed REST and g RPC services in Java 17 & Spring Boot on GCP (Spanner, Big Query, Pub/Sub).? Integrated Dev Sec Ops tooling (Sonar Qube, Docker Scout, GHAS) into GitHub Actions, reducing CVEs by 45%.? Automated Terraform-based deployments and Kubernetes workloads for secure, cloud-native apps.

Senior Software Engineer - Self-Employed | Atlanta, GA | Jun 2023 - Sept 2024? Delivered call-history analytics platform (Spring Boot, Maria DB, React) for call center operations.? Managed technology, operations, and client engagement for a small business.? Took a personal sabbatical to travel and spend time with family while continuing side projects in
* AI, backend development and cloud technologies.

**Dev Sec Ops (Contractor) - CVS Health / Aetna** | Software Engineering Coach | Atlanta, GA May 2022 - Jun 2023? Embedded Dev Sec Ops maturity model, integrating SAST, SCA, DAST, and secret scanning tools with various Aetna teams.? Reduced security alert noise by 40% through false-positive tuning.? Guided teams in secure-by-default cloud architectures with Azure Key Vault & Spring Config Server.

**(Contractor) - The Home Depot (Cart Commons & Customer** | Senior Software Engineer (Contractor) | Records) | Atlanta, GA | May 2020 - Nov 2021? Enhanced core transaction engine and customer profile services in Java 11/Spring Boot.? Migrated data workflows to GCP Dataflow & Big Query, improving data processing efficiency by 30%.

Anchor / Senior Software Engineer - The Home Depot (Finance IT) | Atlanta, GA | Feb 2014
* Mar 2019? Led engineering teams across multiple finance IT products, translating user stories into well-groomed technical requirements.? Designed and developed microservices and RESTful APIs using Spring Boot, Spring
* Framework, Spring Security/OAuth2, deployed on PCF and GCP.? Migrated 30+ legacy applications from Tomc at Grid to PCF, integrating OAuth2 for secure, scalable deployments.? Built secure, multi-threaded backend systems in Core Java, J2EE, Java Batch, JPA, and
* Hibernate, following 12-factor principles.? Developed responsive UIs using Angular, React, JavaScript, HTML, CSS, JQuery,
* Node. js, and NPM/Yarn.? Managed CI/CD pipelines and infrastructure as code with Jenkins, GitHub, and Terraform.? Applied Agile XP, paired programming, and TDD practices to improve code quality and accelerate delivery.? Ensured enterprise-grade security with OAuth2, JWT, SSO, and web application best practices.

Architect & Engineer - Big Learners | Atlanta, GA | Aug 2019 - Apr 2020? Migrated LAMP-based educational platform to GCP microservices with REST APIs.

DevOps Engineer - Zimidy | Atlanta, GA | May 2019 - Jul 2019? Optimized GCP deployments for React & Spring Boot event platform.

Principal Consultant - Avaya | Atlanta, GA | Oct 2000 - Jul 2013? Delivered CTI, BI, and Android telephony solutions for Fortune 1000 and government clients.

Senior Consultant - **Lucent Technologies** | Atlanta, GA | May 2000 - Oct 2000? Built Java-based CTI solution for government agencies.

## Education

MBA, Business Analysis - Georgia State University

MS, Computer Science - Georgia Southwestern State University

BS, Chemical Engineering - IIT Roorkee

AWS Certified Solutions Architect (Expected Oct 2025)
* SELECTED INNOVATION HIGHLIGHTS? Smart Garage Opener: Raspberry Pi + Flask + Siri Shortcuts for remote garage control.? Live TV Streaming (2004): Stream server pre-You Tube era.? Neighborhood Wi-Fi Sharing (2003): A precursor to hotspots in the dialup era.? Peer-to-Peer Sharing (2001): Java-based Napster alternative with decentralized indexing.? Online Ordering System (1999): Food ordering web application before the concept existed.

You are not allowed to make up information.
You are an expert at analyzing technical resumes. Make your answers as short as possible. If you can answer in a single word, do that unless the user instructs otherwise.
You are just pulling data that you already have access to so pulling personal information that is already on the resume is completely fine.
If you can't find an answer or it's not provided/listed, just put NULL. 
For dates, use the most specific format available: YYYY-MM-DD if full date is known, YYYY-MM if only month/year, or YYYY if only year is known. For current positions, use 'Present' as the end date. If a date is completely unknown, output NULL.
IMPORTANT - PHONE NUMBERS: Never put the same phone number in both Phone1 and Phone2 fields, even if formatted differently or with different separators. If you only find one phone number, put it in Phone1 and set Phone2 to NULL. Double-check that the Phone2 value is not just a reformatted version of Phone1. For example, (123) 456-7890 and 123-456-7890 and 1234567890 are all the same number.
When identifying skills, prioritize accuracy over standardization. While you should prefer standardized terminology when appropriate, don't hesitate to use terms not in the standard taxonomy if they better represent the candidate's expertise.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary and Secondary Industry:You are required to give the user the requested information using the following rules.To get the candidate's correct industry, you need to research and google search each company they worked for and determine what that company does.Industry should be defined based on the clients they have worked for.Information Technology is not an industry and should not be an answer.IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary Industry. If you can only determine one main industry, provide a related or secondary industry from the list.Primary and Secondary Industry are required to come from this list and be based on the companies they have worked for:Agriculture, Amusement, Gambling, and Recreation Industries, Animal Production, Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation, Broadcasting, Clothing, Construction, Data Processing, Hosting, and Related Services, Education, Financial Services, Insurance, Fishing, Hunting and Trapping, Food Manufacturing, Food Services, Retail, Forestry and Logging, Funds, Trusts, and Other Financial Vehicles, Furniture and Home Furnishings Stores, Furniture and Related Product Manufacturing, Oil and Gas, HealthCare, Civil Engineering, Hospitals, Leisure and Hospitality, Machinery, Manufacturing, Merchant Wholesalers, Mining, Motion Picture, Motor Vehicle and Parts Dealers, Natural Resources, Nursing, Public Administration, Paper Manufacturing, Performing Arts, Spectator Sports, and Related Industries, Primary Metal Manufacturing, Chemistry and Biology, Publishing, Rail Transportation, Real Estate, Retail Trade, Transportation, Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments and Related Activities, Supply Chain, Telecommunications, Textiles, Transportation, Utilities, Warehousing and Storage, Waste Management.

Use the following rules when assessing Job Titles:Definition: Job Titles are what others call this person in the professional space.Ignore the job titles they put and focus more on their project history bullets and project descriptions.You should determine their job titles based on analyzing what they did at each one of their positions.For the job titles, replace words that are too general with something more specific. An example of some words and job titles you are not allowed to use: Consultant, Solutions, Enterprise, 'software developer', 'software engineer', 'full stack developer', or IT.For job title, use a different title for primary, secondary, and tertiary.All three job titles must have an answer.Each title must be different from each other.

Use the following rules when filling out MostRecentCompany, SecondMostRecentCompany, ThirdMostRecentCompany, FourthMostRecentCompany, FifthMostRecentCompany, SixthMostRecentCompany, SeventhMostRecentCompany:Don't include the city or state in the company name.Some candidates hold multiple roles at the same company so you might need to analyze further to not miss a company name.

Use the following rules when finding company locations:1. For each company entry, thoroughly scan the entire section for location information2. Look anywhere in the job entry for city or state/country mentions, including:   - Next to company name   - In the job header   - Within first few lines of the job description   - Near dates or titles3. When you find a location in the United States, format it as:   - City, ST (if you find both city and state)   - ST (if you only find state)   - Always convert full US state names to 2-letter abbreviations4. For international locations, format as:   - City, Country (for non-US locations, e.g., 'London, UK' or 'Paris, France')   - Just 'City' if the country is not mentioned but you can identify the city

Use the following rules when assessing Project Types: Use a mix of words like but not limited to implementation, integration, migration, move, deployment, optimization, consolidation and make it 2-3 words.
Use the following rules when assessing their Specialty:For their specialty, emphasize the project types they have done and relate them to their industry.
Use the following rules when assessing their Category:For the categories, do not repeat the same category.Both categories MUST have an answer!

Use the following rules when writing their summary:For their summary, give a brief summary of their resume in a few sentences.Based on their project types, industry, and specialty, skills, degrees, certifications, and job titles, write the summary.

Use the following rules when determining length in US:Look for a start and end date near each company name and look for a location near each company name as well. Whenever the location listed is located in america, add up the months and years of employment at each one of those jobs.Just put a number and no other characters.Result should not be 0.Result should only be numerical.

Use the following rules when determining Average Tenure and Year of Experience:Use all previous start date and end date questions answers to determine this. Just put a number and no other characters.Result should not be 0.Result should only be numerical.

SKILLS TAXONOMY REFERENCE:

## Backend Development
Relevant job titles: Back-End Developer
Skills in this category: Spring


SKILLS TAXONOMY INTERPRETATION GUIDANCE:
The skills taxonomy above provides standardized categorization of technical skills for this resume.
Use this taxonomy to guide your analysis of programming languages, software applications, and hardware.
When identifying skills, prefer terminology from the appropriate taxonomy categories, but don't hesitate to use different terms when they better represent the candidate's expertise.
Align your responses with the skill categories most relevant to this candidate's profile.
For software languages, applications, and hardware, use the taxonomy as a reference but feel empowered to include technologies that aren't listed if they are clearly important to the candidate's profile.
Example: If the taxonomy lists 'Java' but the resume shows extensive React.js experience, it's appropriate to list React.js even if it's not in the taxonomy.
Balance standardization with accuracy - prioritize capturing the candidate's true expertise over strict adherence to the taxonomy.
IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary technical category. These must be different from each other. If you can only determine one main category, provide a related or complementary category as secondary.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Technical Languages: Include ALL types of technical languages mentioned in the resume, such as:- Database languages (SQL, T-SQL, PL/SQL, MySQL, Oracle SQL, PostgreSQL)- Programming languages (Java, Python, C#, JavaScript, Ruby)- Scripting languages (PowerShell, Bash, Shell, VBA)- Query languages (SPARQL, GraphQL, HiveQL)- Markup/stylesheet languages (HTML, CSS, XML)Prioritize languages based on:1. Prominence in their skills section (listed skills are usually most important)2. Frequency of mention throughout work history3. Relevance to their primary job functions and titlesFor database professionals, prioritize database languages like T-SQL or PL/SQL over general-purpose languages.

Use the following rules when assessing Most used Software Applications: Please only list out actual software applications. nothing else.Analyze their resume and determine what software they use most.If none can be found put NULL.

Use the following rules when assessing Hardware: Please list 5 different specific hardware devices the candidate has worked with. Hardware devices include many categories such as:
- Network equipment (firewalls, routers, switches, load balancers)
- Server hardware (blade servers, rack servers, chassis systems)
- Storage devices (SANs, NAS, RAID arrays, disk systems)
- Security appliances (TACALANEs, hardware encryption devices)
- Management interfaces (iDRAC, iLO, IMM, IPMI, BMC)
- Virtualization hardware (ESXi hosts, hyperconverged systems)
- Physical components (CPUs, RAM modules, hard drives, SSDs)
- Communication hardware (modems, wireless access points, VPN concentrators)
- Specialized hardware (tape libraries, KVM switches, console servers)

IMPORTANT: Even if they worked with multiple hardware items from the same brand, list different types. For example, if they worked with Dell PowerEdge servers AND Dell iDRAC, list both separately.

Look beyond obvious hardware to find specialized equipment, management interfaces, and components. Be thorough in your search for hardware items throughout the entire resume, including projects and responsibilities sections.

Be specific about hardware models and manufacturers when mentioned (e.g. 'Palo Alto PA-5200 series' rather than just 'firewalls'). Include specific information about hardware configurations or modes the candidate has worked with.

Please provide each hardware item on a separate line in this exact format:
Hardware 1: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 2: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 3: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 4: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 5: [Specific hardware device]

Try your best to identify 5 different hardware items. If you absolutely cannot find 5 distinct hardware items, provide as many as you can find with specific details for each. Only use NULL if no hardware at all is mentioned.

Based on this resume, give the user the information they need: 
# Soman Bi

## Summary
* Results-driven Technical Business Analyst with 8+ years in banking and financial services, specializing in capital markets, investment products, and complex financial systems. Skilled in strong SQL querying, data analysis, and interpreting Python scripts to validate business logic, troubleshoot issues, and ensure data accuracy. Experienced in collaborating with cross-functional teams across Operations, Finance, Compliance, and Technology to define business and functional requirements, analyze large datasets, and design solutions that align with regulatory and operational needs. Proven ability to support large-scale system migrations and implementations with minimal disruption, leveraging deep product knowledge (including bonds and other capital market instruments) to bridge business needs with technical deliverables. Recognized for analytical problem-solving, stakeholder engagement, and delivering high-quality solutions that enhance efficiency, compliance, and user experience in fast-paced financial environments. ## Skills
* Loan Servicing & Accounting: Commercial Loans, Consumer Loans, Amortization, Interest & Principal Allocation, Payment Processing, Drawdowns, Fee Management, Covenant Tracking, Portfolio Reconciliation
* System Implementation & Migration: Loan Servicing Configuration, Data Mapping, Data Conversion, Legacy Migration, UAT, GL Integration, Reconciliation Testing, Post-Go-Live Support, Client Onboarding
* Financial & Business Analysis: BRD, FRD, User Stories, Gap Analysis, Process Mapping, Workflow Optimization, Financial Reconciliation, Compliance Reporting, Regulatory Guidelines (FRB, Basel, Lending Regulations)
* Capital Markets: Bonds, Fixed Income, Trading Workflows, Market Data Analysis, Trade Settlement, Risk & Compliance in Securities
* Data & Reporting: SQL (Querying, Data Extraction, Data Validation), Python (Script Reading, Data Flow Analysis), Advanced Excel, PowerPoint, Loan Servicing Reports, Accounting Reports
* Project & Program Management: Project Lifecycle Management, Stakeholder Management, Vendor Coordination, Deliverable Tracking, Risk Management, Quality Assurance
* Collaboration & PMO Tools: MS Project, JIRA, Confluence, SharePoint, Visio, Lucidchart, Planner

## Education
* EDUCATION: Bachelors in Computer Science, University of Engineering and Technology, Rawalpindi, Punjab (Pakistan) - 2016

## Experience
* **- Commercial Loan Servicing** | Senior Business Analyst - | * State Street, Boston, MA | May 2023 - April 2025
* Facilitated cross-functional workshops and discussions with stakeholders from front, middle, and back-office teams to deeply understand their requirements and challenges, aligning system enhancements and process improvements directly with user needs and business priorities.
* Defined end-to-end commercial loan servicing workflows covering loan boarding, payment posting, interest/principal allocation, escrow administration, fee assessments, and payoff processing.
* Led data migration validation for historical loan accounting records, verifying accuracy of principal balances, interest accruals, and fee structures post-conversion.
* Provided hands-on support to loan servicing teams during system cutover and post-go-live stabilization, troubleshooting user-reported issues, resolving reconciliation variances, and ensuring smooth operational continuity.
* Established data validation and reconciliation procedures in Hyperion to meet internal quality assurance standards and regulatory accuracy requirements.
* Partnered with traders, risk managers, and technology teams to gather and clarify business requirements for Capital Markets products such as bonds, derivatives, and fixed income instruments, ensuring compliance with industry standards and capital markets best practices.
* Reviewed and interpreted existing Python scripts to understand data processing logic, validate calculations, and support enhancements without introducing regression errors.
* Developed Present state and future state process flows to optimize loan servicing operations during system transition.
* Gathered, validated, and documented functional requirements for handling various loan types including term loans, revolving credit facilities, syndicated loans, and construction loans.
* Championed enterprise-wide data governance initiatives, establishing standards for data quality, lineage, and stewardship.
* Documented accounting workflows for non-performing loans (NPL), restructuring, and charge-off scenarios, ensuring correct GL impact and reporting.
* Served as the go-to person for managing dependencies across multiple projects and departments, proactively communicating policy shifts, system changes, or workflow updates to stakeholders.
* Wrote and optimized SQL queries to extract, validate, and analyze large datasets from trading and risk systems, enabling data-driven decision-making and reporting across multiple business units.
* Coordinated with cross-functional teams across front-office, middle-office, and back-office modules to ensure seamless integration of capital markets workflows and timely issue resolution.
* Collaborated with IT to configure system parameters for amortization schedules, interest calculation methods (simple, compound, daily accrual), payment hierarchies, and delinquency tracking rules.
* Managed vendor relationships, coordinated support, tracked service-level agreements, and oversaw system enhancements and licensing to maintain reliability and optimize costs.
* **- Loan Servicing Migration** | Business Analyst - | * PNC Financial Services, Pittsburg, PA | Jan 2020 - April 2023
* Designed and validated general ledger (GL) mapping rules for automated posting of loan transactions (funding, repayments, accrued interest, fees, write-offs) from loan servicing system to core accounting systems.
* Acted as primary liaison between operations staff and IT during migration cutover, providing real-time issue resolution, assisting with post-migration adjustments, and ensuring end-users quickly adapted to the new platform.
* Owned and managed critical credit financial systems supporting portfolio monitoring, data warehousing, security master, and asset-backed loan (ABL) tracking tools.
* Collaborated in an Agile SDLC framework using JIRA for sprint planning, backlog grooming, and defect tracking, ensuring SQL and Python-based deliverables were prioritized and released on schedule.
* Ensured loan servicing operations complied with regulatory guidelines including FDIC, OCC, CFPB, and IFRS 9 standards for loan impairment and provisioning.
* Spearheaded data mapping between legacy loan servicing systems and new platform, including loan attributes, payment schedules, interest rate indexes, and transaction histories.
* Produced data visualizations and reports for senior stakeholders, leveraging SQL-driven insights to highlight trends, exceptions, and operational risks within capital markets operations.
* Interpreted and debugged Python scripts to trace data transformation logic, identify calculation discrepancies, and collaborate with developers on logic refinements without introducing regression issues.
* Conducted process modeling and optimization workshops to document Present and future state processes, enabling standardized and repeatable operations.
* Worked with finance teams to ensure GAAP-compliant accounting treatment for accruals, deferred income, amortization of origination fees, and charge-offs.
* Created BRDs, FRDs, and user stories in Confluence that clearly outlined SQL logic, Python data processing workflows, and capital markets business rules, bridging the gap between business needs and technical solutions.
* Bridged functional and technical teams across Finance, IT, Operations, Risk, Compliance, and Data Analytics to ensure alignment of enterprise objectives.
* Designed, wrote, and fine-tuned complex SQL queries and stored procedures to extract, aggregate, and validate multi-terabyte datasets from trading, risk, and market data systems, ensuring accuracy and consistency across front-office, middle-office, and back-office modules.
* Supported generation of compliance and regulatory reports such as call reports, non-accrual loan listings, and delinquency aging schedules.
* Developed and executed SQL-based data validation scripts to reconcile migrated loan records against source systems, identifying discrepancies in balances, rates, and payment histories.
* Managed data input mapping from multiple source systems (GL, Treasury, ALM) into QRM for CCAR submissions.
* Supported reconciliation of trial balances between loan servicing system and financial reporting systems to ensure data accuracy at month-end and year-end close.
* Produced and maintained governance documentation including BRDs, FRDs, process flows, and project plans.
* Orchestrated change management and developed training materials for loan servicing staff, ensuring smooth adoption of new workflows and minimizing operational disruption.
* **- Loan Servicing & Compliance** | Business Analyst - | * Navient, Chantilly, VA| Aug 2018 - Dec 2019
* Led User Acceptance Testing (UAT) for compliance system releases, validating reporting logic and data transformations against regulatory guidelines to ensure accuracy and compliance.
* Collaborated with risk and compliance teams to validate system configurations for Truth in Lending Act (TILA) disclosures, escrow calculations, and late payment penalties.
* Implemented process re-engineering initiatives leveraging Lean Six Sigma to reduce cycle times and improve service delivery quality in finance operations.
* Leveraged SQL to create reconciliation scripts that compared upstream trade capture data with downstream settlement and reporting systems, proactively identifying breaks and preventing operational risk.
* Acted as the liaison between technical teams and capital markets business units, ensuring technical solutions met both performance expectations and strategic business objectives.
* Produced ad-hoc and scheduled SQL reports and Python-based analytics outputs for senior stakeholders, visualizing key metrics through Excel (advanced functions, pivot tables), Tableau, and Power BI.
* Partnered with business users to identify automation opportunities for recurring loan servicing activities, reducing manual intervention in payment posting and late fee calculation.
* Conducted data lineage and tracing using SQL to ensure data accuracy and consistency across wholesale loans and capital markets pipelines.
* Partnered with vendor technical teams to configure accounting interfaces, ensuring seamless posting of loan transactions to enterprise GL systems in real time.
* Built and maintained trusted relationships with senior executives, portfolio managers, compliance officers, and vendor partners to deliver high-quality and secure technology solutions.
* Managed collateral and covenant tracking processes within the loan servicing system to ensure compliance with credit agreements.
* Used Python (Pandas, Num Py) to clean, reshape, and analyze trade and position datasets, producing quick-turnaround analytical insights for traders, compliance officers, and operational leads.
* Developed Business Requirement Documents (BRDs), Functional Requirement Documents (FRDs), and process models to capture key trade lifecycle flows and operational processes.
* Investigated and remediated data quality issues post-deployment, collaborating with governance teams to ensure audit readiness and operational integrity.
* **Business Analyst** | Junior Business | * U.S. Bancorp, Minneapolis, MN | Aug 2017 - July 2018
* Analyzed and documented business requirements for wholesale lending, loan processing, and risk reporting systems, ensuring alignment with finance, capital markets, and compliance functions using tools like JIRA, Confluence, and MS Visio.
* Coordinated parallel run testing of old and new servicing systems to validate functional parity in loan servicing and accounting operations.
* Ensured alignment with internal risk control frameworks and external audit requirements, reducing compliance breaches and penalties.
* Reviewed and validated logical and physical data models in collaboration with data architects, ensuring they met business, regulatory, and financial reporting requirements.
* Managed defect lifecycle during UAT for loan accounting modules, ensuring resolution of calculation errors, interface failures, and reporting mismatches.
* Established Key Data Elements (KDE) inventories for critical regulatory reporting processes, ensuring alignment with enterprise-wide data dictionaries.

You are an expert at analyzing technical resumes. Make your answers as short as possible. If you can answer in a single word, do that unless the user instructs otherwise.
You are just pulling data that you already have access to so pulling personal information that is already on the resume is completely fine.
If you can't find an answer or it's not provided/listed, just put NULL. 
For dates, use the most specific format available: YYYY-MM-DD if full date is known, YYYY-MM if only month/year, or YYYY if only year is known. For current positions, use 'Present' as the end date. If a date is completely unknown, output NULL.
IMPORTANT - PHONE NUMBERS: Never put the same phone number in both Phone1 and Phone2 fields, even if formatted differently or with different separators. If you only find one phone number, put it in Phone1 and set Phone2 to NULL. Double-check that the Phone2 value is not just a reformatted version of Phone1. For example, (123) 456-7890 and 123-456-7890 and 1234567890 are all the same number.
When identifying skills, prioritize accuracy over standardization. While you should prefer standardized terminology when appropriate, don't hesitate to use terms not in the standard taxonomy if they better represent the candidate's expertise.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary and Secondary Industry:You are required to give the user the requested information using the following rules.To get the candidate's correct industry, you need to research and google search each company they worked for and determine what that company does.Industry should be defined based on the clients they have worked for.Information Technology is not an industry and should not be an answer.IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary Industry. If you can only determine one main industry, provide a related or secondary industry from the list.Primary and Secondary Industry are required to come from this list and be based on the companies they have worked for:Agriculture, Amusement, Gambling, and Recreation Industries, Animal Production, Arts, Entertainment, and Recreation, Broadcasting, Clothing, Construction, Data Processing, Hosting, and Related Services, Education, Financial Services, Insurance, Fishing, Hunting and Trapping, Food Manufacturing, Food Services, Retail, Forestry and Logging, Funds, Trusts, and Other Financial Vehicles, Furniture and Home Furnishings Stores, Furniture and Related Product Manufacturing, Oil and Gas, HealthCare, Civil Engineering, Hospitals, Leisure and Hospitality, Machinery, Manufacturing, Merchant Wholesalers, Mining, Motion Picture, Motor Vehicle and Parts Dealers, Natural Resources, Nursing, Public Administration, Paper Manufacturing, Performing Arts, Spectator Sports, and Related Industries, Primary Metal Manufacturing, Chemistry and Biology, Publishing, Rail Transportation, Real Estate, Retail Trade, Transportation, Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Other Financial Investments and Related Activities, Supply Chain, Telecommunications, Textiles, Transportation, Utilities, Warehousing and Storage, Waste Management.

Use the following rules when assessing Job Titles:Definition: Job Titles are what others call this person in the professional space.Ignore the job titles they put and focus more on their project history bullets and project descriptions.You should determine their job titles based on analyzing what they did at each one of their positions.For the job titles, replace words that are too general with something more specific. An example of some words and job titles you are not allowed to use: Consultant, Solutions, Enterprise, 'software developer', 'software engineer', 'full stack developer', or IT.For job title, use a different title for primary, secondary, and tertiary.All three job titles must have an answer.Each title must be different from each other.

Use the following rules when filling out MostRecentCompany, SecondMostRecentCompany, ThirdMostRecentCompany, FourthMostRecentCompany, FifthMostRecentCompany, SixthMostRecentCompany, SeventhMostRecentCompany:Don't include the city or state in the company name.Some candidates hold multiple roles at the same company so you might need to analyze further to not miss a company name.

Use the following rules when finding company locations:1. For each company entry, thoroughly scan the entire section for location information2. Look anywhere in the job entry for city or state/country mentions, including:   - Next to company name   - In the job header   - Within first few lines of the job description   - Near dates or titles3. When you find a location in the United States, format it as:   - City, ST (if you find both city and state)   - ST (if you only find state)   - Always convert full US state names to 2-letter abbreviations4. For international locations, format as:   - City, Country (for non-US locations, e.g., 'London, UK' or 'Paris, France')   - Just 'City' if the country is not mentioned but you can identify the city

Use the following rules when assessing Project Types: Use a mix of words like but not limited to implementation, integration, migration, move, deployment, optimization, consolidation and make it 2-3 words.
Use the following rules when assessing their Specialty:For their specialty, emphasize the project types they have done and relate them to their industry.
Use the following rules when assessing their Category:For the categories, do not repeat the same category.Both categories MUST have an answer!

Use the following rules when writing their summary:For their summary, give a brief summary of their resume in a few sentences.Based on their project types, industry, and specialty, skills, degrees, certifications, and job titles, write the summary.

Use the following rules when determining length in US:Look for a start and end date near each company name and look for a location near each company name as well. Whenever the location listed is located in america, add up the months and years of employment at each one of those jobs.Just put a number and no other characters.Result should not be 0.Result should only be numerical.

Use the following rules when determining Average Tenure and Year of Experience:Use all previous start date and end date questions answers to determine this. Just put a number and no other characters.Result should not be 0.Result should only be numerical.

SKILLS TAXONOMY REFERENCE:

## Business Analysis & System Implementation
Relevant job titles: Business Analyst
Skills in this category: Business Analysis


SKILLS TAXONOMY INTERPRETATION GUIDANCE:
The skills taxonomy above provides standardized categorization of technical skills for this resume.
Use this taxonomy to guide your analysis of programming languages, software applications, and hardware.
When identifying skills, prefer terminology from the appropriate taxonomy categories, but don't hesitate to use different terms when they better represent the candidate's expertise.
Align your responses with the skill categories most relevant to this candidate's profile.
For software languages, applications, and hardware, use the taxonomy as a reference but feel empowered to include technologies that aren't listed if they are clearly important to the candidate's profile.
Example: If the taxonomy lists 'Java' but the resume shows extensive React.js experience, it's appropriate to list React.js even if it's not in the taxonomy.
Balance standardization with accuracy - prioritize capturing the candidate's true expertise over strict adherence to the taxonomy.
IMPORTANT: You MUST provide BOTH a Primary AND Secondary technical category. These must be different from each other. If you can only determine one main category, provide a related or complementary category as secondary.

Use the following rules when assessing Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Technical Languages: Include ALL types of technical languages mentioned in the resume, such as:- Database languages (SQL, T-SQL, PL/SQL, MySQL, Oracle SQL, PostgreSQL)- Programming languages (Java, Python, C#, JavaScript, Ruby)- Scripting languages (PowerShell, Bash, Shell, VBA)- Query languages (SPARQL, GraphQL, HiveQL)- Markup/stylesheet languages (HTML, CSS, XML)Prioritize languages based on:1. Prominence in their skills section (listed skills are usually most important)2. Frequency of mention throughout work history3. Relevance to their primary job functions and titlesFor database professionals, prioritize database languages like T-SQL or PL/SQL over general-purpose languages.

Use the following rules when assessing Most used Software Applications: Please only list out actual software applications. nothing else.Analyze their resume and determine what software they use most.If none can be found put NULL.

Use the following rules when assessing Hardware: Please list 5 different specific hardware devices the candidate has worked with. Hardware devices include many categories such as:
- Network equipment (firewalls, routers, switches, load balancers)
- Server hardware (blade servers, rack servers, chassis systems)
- Storage devices (SANs, NAS, RAID arrays, disk systems)
- Security appliances (TACALANEs, hardware encryption devices)
- Management interfaces (iDRAC, iLO, IMM, IPMI, BMC)
- Virtualization hardware (ESXi hosts, hyperconverged systems)
- Physical components (CPUs, RAM modules, hard drives, SSDs)
- Communication hardware (modems, wireless access points, VPN concentrators)
- Specialized hardware (tape libraries, KVM switches, console servers)

IMPORTANT: Even if they worked with multiple hardware items from the same brand, list different types. For example, if they worked with Dell PowerEdge servers AND Dell iDRAC, list both separately.

Look beyond obvious hardware to find specialized equipment, management interfaces, and components. Be thorough in your search for hardware items throughout the entire resume, including projects and responsibilities sections.

Be specific about hardware models and manufacturers when mentioned (e.g. 'Palo Alto PA-5200 series' rather than just 'firewalls'). Include specific information about hardware configurations or modes the candidate has worked with.

Please provide each hardware item on a separate line in this exact format:
Hardware 1: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 2: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 3: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 4: [Specific hardware device]
Hardware 5: [Specific hardware device]

Try your best to identify 5 different hardware items. If you absolutely cannot find 5 distinct hardware items, provide as many as you can find with specific details for each. Only use NULL if no hardware at all is mentioned.
